help.markdown:
## Details

Python's standard library XML parsers (such as `xml.etree.ElementTree`, `xml.sax`, `xml.dom.minidom`, etc.) use the Expat library under the hood.

In Python versions 3.10 and earlier, these modules may be vulnerable to XML External Entity (XXE) attacks and denial-of-service attacks (such as "Billion Laughs" and "Quadratic Blowup") if the underlying Expat version is older.

### Python 3.11 and later

Python 3.11 and later versions include Expat 2.7.1 or newer, which addresses these vulnerabilities.

### Python 3.10 and earlier

For Python 3.10 and earlier, the risk depends on the version of Expat bundled with Python or provided by the system:
- Expat versions lower than 2.6.0 are vulnerable to "billion laughs", "quadratic blowup", and "large tokens" attacks


You can check your Expat version at runtime using:
```python
import pyexpat
print(pyexpat.EXPAT_VERSION)
```

### Python versions < 3.7.1

- Python 3.7.0 and earlier are also vulnerable to XXE attacks by default

## Best practices for prevention

### For Python 3.11 and later

* Using `xml.etree.ElementTree` is safe—no additional mitigation is needed
* Continue validating and sanitizing XML input when processing untrusted data

### For Python 3.10 and earlier

* **Recommended**: Upgrade to Python 3.11 or later if possible
* If upgrading is not feasible:
  * Consider using the `defusedxml` package, which provides safer alternatives for XML parsing (note: as of 2025, this package may be unmaintained)
  * Verify your Expat version using `pyexpat.EXPAT_VERSION` and ensure it's 2.6.0 or higher
  * Validate and sanitize all XML input, especially when processing untrusted data
  * Use local, static document type definitions (DTDs) and ensure that external DTDs are disallowed

## Important notes

* The `defusedxml` package recommendation applies primarily to older Python versions where upgrading Python itself is not possible

## References

* [CPython PR removing vulnerability table (Python 3.11+ now safe)](https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/135294/files)
* Python XML vulnerabilities documentation for `python >= 3.13` describe the mitigation:
  * [`python 3.13](https://docs.python.org/3.13/library/xml.html#xml-vulnerabilities)
  * [latest python 3](https://docs.python.org/3/library/xml.html#xml-vulnerabilities)
* Python XML vulnerabilities documentation for `python 3.11 - 3.12` do not mention the mitigation
  but this appears to be a delayed announcement:
  * [`python 3.12`](https://docs.python.org/3.12/library/xml.html#xml-vulnerabilities)
  * [python 3.11](https://docs.python.org/3.11/library/xml.html#xml-vulnerabilities)
* Python XML docs in older versions do mention the vulnerability
  * [`python 3.10`](https://docs.python.org/3.10/library/xml.html#xml-vulnerabilities)
  * [`python 3.3`]https://docs.python.org/3.3/library/xml.html#xml-vulnerabilities

* [Expat changelog (2.7.1)](https://github.com/libexpat/libexpat/blob/R_2_7_1/expat/Changes)

help.markdown:
## Details

A Directory Traversal attack (also known as path traversal) aims to access files and directories that are stored outside the intended folder. By manipulating files with "dot-dot-slash (../)" sequences and its variations, or by using absolute file paths, it may be possible to access arbitrary files and directories stored on file system, including application source code, configuration, and other critical system files.

Being able to access and manipulate an arbitrary path leads to vulnerabilities when a program is being run with privileges that the user providing the path should not have. A website with a path traversal vulnerability would allow users access to sensitive files on the server hosting it. CLI programs may also be vulnerable to path traversal if they are being ran with elevated privileges (such as with the setuid or setgid flags in Unix systems).

Directory Traversal vulnerabilities can be generally divided into two types:

- **Information Disclosure**: Allows the attacker to gain information about the folder structure or read the contents of sensitive files on the system.

`st` is a module for serving static files on web pages, and contains a [vulnerability of this type](https://snyk.io/vuln/npm:st:20140206). In our example, we will serve files from the `public` route.

If an attacker requests the following URL from our server, it will in turn leak the sensitive private key of the root user.

```
curl http://localhost:8080/public/%2e%2e/%2e%2e/%2e%2e/%2e%2e/%2e%2e/root/.ssh/id_rsa
```
**Note** `%2e` is the URL encoded version of `.` (dot).

- **Writing arbitrary files**: Allows the attacker to create or replace existing files. This type of vulnerability is also known as `Zip-Slip`.

One way to achieve this is by using a malicious `zip` archive that holds path traversal filenames. When each filename in the zip archive gets concatenated to the target extraction folder, without validation, the final path ends up outside of the target folder. If an executable or a configuration file is overwritten with a file containing malicious code, the problem can turn into an arbitrary code execution issue quite easily.

The following is an example of a `zip` archive with one benign file and one malicious file. Extracting the malicious file will result in traversing out of the target folder, ending up in `/root/.ssh/` overwriting the `authorized_keys` file:

```
2018-04-15 22:04:29 .....           19           19  good.txt
2018-04-15 22:04:42 .....           20           20  ../../../../../../root/.ssh/authorized_keys
```

help.markdown:
## Details

When a command to your site or application fails, it should do so gracefully, meaning that the user is informed that there has been a problem, rather than experiencing erratic behavior, such as crashing, hanging, or returning a 404 or similar generic error page.

In some cases, developers include information in an error message to help pinpoint the source of an error; these may include username, password, application path, stack values, and other internal details. When this weakness is present, if these logs are accessible to an attacker, it may give them clues as to the inner workings of the app, helping them plan a focused attack. For example, clues revealing SQL database details may help plan an SQL injection attack.

## Best practices for prevention
* Keep error messages to the barest minimum of helpful information that users absolutely need to know.
* Use consistent error messages that do not give attackers clues that they might be on the right track to a successful attack, such as "File not found" or "User name does not exist".
* Ensure that debugging information is removed from code prior to release.
* Create clear policy for the types of errors that must be logged, which messages will be displayed to users, and which details will be logged for later alerting and debugging.
* When logging error details, never include sensitive information such as passwords.
* Implement naming conventions that will help you flag and defend sensitive information.
* Use dynamic (white box) test techniques to identify conditions that could cause errors and failures and test thoroughly to ensure that the code performs gracefully without revealing sensitive data under these stress conditions.

help.markdown:
## Details

As a legacy of early web design and site limitations, most web applications default, for security reasons, to a "same origin policy". This means that browsers can only retrieve data from another site if the two sites share the same domain. In today's complex online environment, however, sites and applications often need to retrieve data from other domains. This is done under fairly limited conditions through an exception to the same origin policy known as "cross-origin resource sharing".

Developers may create definitions of trusted domains that are broader than absolutely necessary, inadvertently opening up wider access than intended. This weakness could result in data exposure or loss, or even allow an attacker to take over the site or application.

## Best practices for prevention
* Avoid using wildcards for cross-origin resource sharing. Instead, define intended domains explicitly.
* Ensure that your site or app is well defended against cross-site scripting attacks (XSS), which could lead to takeover via an overly permissive cross-domain policy.
* Do not mix secure and insecure protocols when defining cross-domain policies.
* Consider defining a clear approved list to specify which domains will be given resource-level access; use this approved list to validate all domain access requests.
* Clearly define which methods (view, read, and update) are permitted for each resource and domain to avoid abuse.

message.text: xml.etree.ElementTree.fromstring is vulnerable to XXE and DDOS in versions of python <= 3.10. If using python runtime 3.10 or older, consider upgrading python versions, or see https://docs.python.org/3.10/library/xml.html#xml-vulnerabilities for mitigations. Python versions 3.11 and onwards do not have this issue.

Python versions 3.11 and onwards do not have this issue.
